review.title: Elections with Few Voters: Candidate Control Can Be Easy
review.abstract: We study the computational complexity of candidate control in elections with few voters (that is, we take the number of voters as a parameter). We consider both the standard scenario of adding and deleting candidates, where one asks if a given candidate can become a winner (or, in the destructive case, can be precluded from winning) by adding/deleting some candidates, and a combinatorial scenario where adding/deleting a candidate automatically means adding/deleting a whole group of candidates. Our results show that the parameterized complexity of candidate control (with the number of voters as the parameter) is much more varied than in the setting with many voters.
histories: 52 pages. to appear in the Twenty-Ninth AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-15)
56 pages, short version presented at AAAI-2015
review.COMMENTS: 52 pages. to appear in the Twenty-Ninth AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-15)

sections.heading: 3 Overview of Proof Techniques
sections.text: We present several evidentiary techniques that may be useful to investigate the complexity of the electoral problems parameterized by the number of voters. We use the following techniques (the first two are perhaps the most interesting): Multi-Colored Clique Technique. This is a technique used to establish W [1] hardness results. The idea is to give a reduction of MULTI-COLORED CLIQUE (MCC) parameterized by the clique order (a variant of the standard CLIQUE problem that is better suited to the parameterized complexity results, where each vertex has one of h colors, and we seek a clique of the order h with a different color).

sections.heading: 4 Approval-Based Rules
sections.text: In this section, we look at t-Approval and t-Veto rules differently. These are perhaps the simplest and most commonly used rules, so the results are of particular interest in relation to them. We start by looking at the plurality rule and the veto rule. However, in terms of standard complexity theory, control by adding / deleting candidates (constructive and destructive) is NP-complete for both candidates (Bartholdi et al. [1]; Hemaspaandra et al. [18]) However, when we parameterise the number of candidates, the results change quite drastically. On the one hand, the results for analog types of (non-combinatorial) control for these rules are different (for example, plurality CCDC is in FPT, but veto CCDC is W [1] -hard; this is quite unexpected given the similarity and simplicity of plurality and veto), and on the other hand, comatorial and non-control classes.

sections.heading: 5 Other Voting Rules
sections.text: We focus on the electoral rules we know, and on Maximin 5. The results are very different from those we have in the case of t-approval and t-veto.

sections.heading: 6 Outlook
sections.text: Our work motivates several lines of research. One particularly interesting aspect is the consideration of game theory aspects of candidate control: the results of traceability motivate us to examine more involved settings (e.g. we consider a setting in which two actors try to exclude two different candidates from victory; their goals could involve both cooperation and competition); and finally, we believe that the case of a small number of voters has not received enough attention in the literature for calculating social choices, and many other problems related to this parameter can (and should) be investigated.

sections.heading: A Overview
sections.text: In the appendix we find all the proofs that are missing from the main text, but the appendix is organized differently from the essay. Instead of ordering the results in terms of the voting rules and problems examined, we sort them in terms of the proofreading method. Next, we establish a link between the organization of the body of the text and the appendix. That is, for each of the theorems from the body of the text, we provide in this appendix a proof that points the reader to suitable terms proven in the following sections. We believe that in this way, on the one hand, the essay shows how our results relate to each other, and on the other hand, the appendix is short and coherent.

sections.heading: A.1 Road Map
sections.text: That is, for each of the theorems from the main body of the text we will list the results in which the respective parts of the theorem are proven for the respective way. sections.heading: B Multi-Colored Clique Technique
sections.text: In this section we give the proofs based on the MULTI-COLORED CLIQUE technique. Specifically, we substantiate the following statements (all results refer to parameterization by number of voters): 1. For each fixed integer and for each electoral rule R {t-Approval, t-Veto}, RCCAC (and therefore R-COMB-CCAC) is W [1] -hard.3. For each fixed integer T and for each electoral rule R {veto, t-Approval, t-Veto}, t-Veto}, R-CCDC is W [1] -hard.3. For each fixed integer T and for each electoral rule R {t-Veto}, t-Veto}, RCOMB-DCAC is W [1] -hard.All the proofs follow through reductions of MULTI-COLORED CLIQUE (hence of the name of the technique) and we are quite similar.

sections.heading: C Cubic Vertex Cover Technique
sections.text: In this section we give the proofs based on the CUBIC VERTEX COVER classic four. The idea is to prove the para-NP hardness by a set number of votes. Formally, the CUBIC VERTEX COVER problem is defined as follows. Definition 3: An instance of CUBIC VERTEX COVER consists of a graph G = (G), E (G), in which each vertex of G is defined as exactly three and a non-negative integer h. Definition 3: An instance of CUBIC VERTEX COVER consists of a graph G = (G), E (G), in which each vertex of G is exactly three, and a non-negative integer h. We ask if there is a subset (vertex coverage) of at most h-vertex, so that each edge becomes at least one vertex in the subset.All our reductions in this section use the following setup.

sections.heading: D Set-Embedding Technique for Combinatorial Variants
sections.text: In this section we give the proofs based on the set embedding technique for the combinatorial variants of our control problems. Specifically, we prove the following statements (all results are intended for parameterization by the number of voters): 1. For each fixed integer t and for each electoral rule r-Approval, t-Veto, d-Veto, d-Veto (for 0 ≤ 1), R-COMB-DCDC is para-NP-hard.2. For each fixed integer t and for each electoral rule r-Approval, t-Veto, d-Veto, B-COMB-CCDC is para-NP-hard.3. For each fixed integer t-En and for each individual electoral rule r-En, t-Veto, t-Veto, d-Veto, b-COMB-CCDC is para-NP-hard.3. For each electoral rule r-COMB-hard.s we have the same elective rule, COMB-Va-CC.Va-V.4 is

sections.heading: E Signature Technique for Destructive Control
sections.text: In this section we consider only t-approval and t-veto elections. We let d indicate the despised candidate whom we want to exclude from the election. Without loss of universality we assume that d is a winner in the original election.We observe that for a candidate p = d, for a specific election, an arbitrary candidate c / p, d} only three possible relative positions compared to candidates d and p (typically the goal of the candidate will be to defeat the despised candidate): either c stands in front of both, behind both, or between them. Thus, in an election with n voters, each candidate can be characterized by a vector. We call such vectors signature signature signature signature signature signature signature signature, which the despised candidate c.

(It is as if we have determined the number of "relevant" relevant "candidates (or the number of" relevant "candidates) in a function of the parameter n, and the search for an optimal solution in a raw way via this" kernel. "This type of" kernel ization "is called Turing-Signature Binkele-Raible et al. [5] Schizer [31] as follows.

sections.heading: E.2 Deleting Candidates
sections.text: The (Turing) kernelization approach in the case of candidate addition cannot simply be transferred to the case of candidate deletion. This is because we cannot limit the number of candidates that need to be deleted in terms of the number of voters. (We will now describe our approach by considering the remaining task as an integer linear program (ILP), we can represent an instance of t-Approval-DCDC where V = (v1, v2, vn). (We will focus on the case of tApproval and later will argue how we apply the results to the case of t-veto.) We advise a candidate p whose role is to defeat the despised candidate d.

sections.heading: F Brute-Force Search
sections.text: In this section, we use the brute force search to get all the XP results in this essay and some other FPT results. We note that all of these algorithms can be easily customized to solve the optimization versions of the related problems.

sections.heading: F.1 FPT Results
sections.text: The main idea for the fixed-parameter tractability results in this section is to guess a subset of voters who have a specific candidate one point below either plurality or veto. The point is that in case of deletion of candidates this subset of voters is considered trivial to delete the number of candidates. This is presented in the procedure CollectCands (), which can be solved in algorithm 2.Lemma 30. Plurality-CCDC can be solved in O (m · n) time, in which the number of voters and m is the number of candidates in the initial election. Proof. Let me: (C, V, k) be a plurality-CCDC instance. If I am a yes instance, then there must be a subset of voters, and no other candidate.

sections.heading: G Miscellaneous Results
sections.text: Theorem 8. Maximin-COMB-DCAC is a bundle of polynomial time solvable. Evidence. It has been shown by Faliszewski et al. [16] that Maximin-DCAC is a bundle of polynomial time solvable. The same strategy can also be applied in the combinatorial case. The algorithm is very simple and can be described as follows: We guess up to two bundles of candidates, add them to the election and check if the despised candidate d is no longer a winner, if so, we accept him otherwise. To see why this simple algorithm is correct, let us consider a solution. If the solution consists of no more than two bundles, then we are done. Otherwise, let us look more closely at the solution. It is clear that in the solution d there is no winner, therefore there must be at least one other candidate who gives a higher than d. Let us consider a bundle bp in the solution that includes p (there could actually be several such bundles, and we can select one candidate).

Our results (see Table 1; formal definitions follow in the next section) are of four types (with the exception of t-Veto-Comb-DCAC which is only in XP): for each of our problems we show that it either is in P, is in FPT, is W[1]-hard but has an XP-algorithm, or is paraNP-hard (in each case the parameter is the number of voters).

The third kind is less positive (W[1]-hardness precludes existence of FPT algorithms, but membership in XP means that there are algorithms that are polynomial-time if the number of voters is a constant).

On the one hand, the results for analogous types of (non-combinatorial) control for these rules differ (for example, Plurality-CCDC is in FPT but Veto-CCDC is W[1]-hard; this is quite unexpected given the similarity and simplicity of Plurality and Veto), and, on the other hand, combinatorial and non-combinatorial control problems behave differently.
For example, in combinatorial control, the deleting candidates case is para-NP-hard for all the rules, but the adding candidates case is either in FPT or W[1]-hard (but in XP).

When parameterized by the number of voters, (1) for Plurality and Veto, DCAC and DCDC are both in FPT, (2) Plurality-CCAC and Veto-CCAC are both W[1]-hard, and (3) Plurality-CCDC is in FPT, while Veto-CCDC is W[1]-hard.

For t-Approval and t-Veto with t ≥ 2, there are fewer surprises and patterns are more clearly visible: In the non-combinatorial setting, constructive controls are W[1]-hard and the destructive ones are in FPT.

When parameterized by the number of voters, for each fixed integer t ≥ 2, for t-Approval and t-Veto, (1) (COMB)-CCAC, and CCDC are W[1]-hard, (2) DCAC and DCDC are in FPT, (3) COMB-CCDC and COMB-DCDC are para-NP-hard, and (4) t-ApprovalCOMB-DCAC is W[1]-hard.

In this section, we establish XP results for all our W[1]-hard problems.

metadata.abstractText: We study the computational complexity of candidate control in elections with few voters (that is, we take the number of voters as a parameter). We consider both the standard scenario of adding and deleting candidates, where one asks if a given candidate can become a winner (or, in the destructive case, can be precluded from winning) by adding/deleting some candidates, and a combinatorial scenario where adding/deleting a candidate automatically means adding/deleting a whole group of candidates. Our results show that the parameterized complexity of candidate control (with the number of voters as the parameter) is much more varied than in the setting with many voters.
